title: 106_s2347
content: The "Information Technology Act of 2000" may be cited as the short title for this Act. It includes definitions for various terms used within the Act. The "Information Technology Act of 2000" defines terms such as certified commercial information technology training provider, dislocated worker, and information technology certification. The term "information technology certification" refers to certification in information technology, issued by various professional associations or state boards after consultation with education officers and other relevant entities. The term "information technology training program" refers to a program for training computer programmers, systems analysts, computer scientists, engineers, and other relevant occupations approved by the Secretaries after consultation with various entities. The curr_chunk defines key terms such as "institution of higher education," "Native American," "Secretaries," and "veteran" in relation to relevant legislation. The curr_chunk focuses on information technology training program grants. The Secretaries may provide grants for information technology training programs for various groups, including minorities, women, veterans, and dislocated workers. Eligible partnerships must include an institution of higher education and a private organization. Partnerships must submit an application to receive a grant. The Federal government will cover 50% of the costs for information technology training programs, with the remaining share to be provided in cash or in kind. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2001, with additional funds available for subsequent years. Bonus grants are available for information technology certification under Section 4. The Secretary of Education may grant bonuses to teachers achieving information technology certification, with a maximum amount of $5,000 per teacher. Local educational agencies must apply for the grant by providing necessary information on the number of eligible teachers. The Secretary of Education may grant bonuses to teachers who have achieved information technology certification and meet certain criteria, including not having received awards previously and committing to teach for at least 3 years after receiving the bonus. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2001 through 2005 to carry out this section.
